annotation.TEXT: With that being said however, it's been a long time since I've played this initial entry. I can already tell you one thing though: It's nowhere near as good or polished as its sequel (for several obvious reasons).

I'll be honest: The main reason I'm doing Air Man's stage now is just to get it out of the way. All of the problems the original one had are amplified several times over in this version. Some of Fire Man's limitations also don't help matters.

Also, since it's pretty apparent by now, I apologize for how jumpy some of the footage is here. I personally blame a combination of my old PC and Wood Man's stage graphics not mixing well. In the very least, it won't do this for every section (and it stops on the next stage as well).

Cut Man here is pretty basic in terms of mechanics. His Rolling Cutters follow the same arcing path that his original ones did, and they deal multiple hits as they linger inside an enemy's sprite. Given this, positioning him well for your attacks is important - especially since you can only use one Rolling Cutter at a time.

To top all the waiting (and that last Fan Fiend) off, Air Man is downright obnoxious. The Fire Storm will actually ignite the oncoming tornados and cause them to move faster. Since Air Man is almost constantly firing them, there's virtually no way to avoid hitting one. That's also not to mention they cancel out your shot, meaning you have to constantly fire if you even hope to do some damage to him. Oh, and just like in the original, some of the tornado patterns are completely unavoidable at times.

Fire Man's main gimmick is that he can light up these torches (or maybe they're supposed to be candle strings). Once lit, they begin producing cloud platforms that float upwards, similar to the ones from Snake Man's stage (although these ones thankfully don't sway from left to right).

The hanging platforms are where you really need to be careful. Obviously, cutting the vines causes the platforms to fall. However, once you cut a platform, it doesn't respawn - and some of them are necessary to keep around in order to advance (and in turn, forcing you to die if you accidentally cut one you weren't supposed to).

Here's where some of the worst aspects of the level start to come out. Air Man's gimmicks were already tedious due to them involving waiting. In the very least however, the original level was short, so it evened it out somewhat. Not only is this version much longer, but the new gimmicks/layouts - while interesting in some aspects - all involve waiting. Believe me, it gets to be tiresome very quickly.

Since I'm going in order, I'll probably do DL2 after this (for obvious reasons), followed by Next Remix. For now though, let's focus on one thing at a time with the current game. So then, who here hasn't imagined playing a Mega Man game as their favorite Robot Master before?

So then, more waiting time and one death later (because seriously, did you really want to see that?). The next section introduces the Fan Fiends, who are equally annoying as everything else in this stage. The main problem is that their wind effect can actually kick in before they fully emerge on-screen, which can cause you to either be pushed back or get knocked into an enemy without much notice.

It's not like this goes on for a little bit through certain intervals like the cloud platforms, either. Each and every segment of the last stretch in this level involves waiting around in some form or another, and it tends overstay its welcome more often than not. The prime example is with this messed up layout right here.

Just to note, the transition effect here is to skip a death to save time. Then again, it's not like Wood Man himself is that difficult. He follows roughly the same pattern as his original, but you can now cut through his leaves (or at least, certain ones when he puts up his shield). The falling variants also cover the whole length of the screen, so you need to get rid of them to avoid damage (or you could also wail on him while he's standing still - that is, if your health is high enough).

Just to note, it's easier to mess this part up than you think. You actually can't jump through the cloud platforms, since the top portion counts as a solid object (even though power-ups fall right through it if you kill a Kaminari Goro while it's riding one). This means you can't just leap up to a platform if one is above you, which can easily mess you over for the last jump here. It's also what causes me to accidentally miss the opportunity to do so here.

It's a pretty novel idea, to say the least. Aside from Powered Up (and technically a few entries in the Battle Network series), I don't think any other official game in the series allows for it. With fan-games however, it's a much different story. While the first "Day in the Limelight" game might not have been the first to do this sort of thing, it's still probably one of the more notable examples.

Fire Man himself basically controls like Mega Man, although he can jump slightly higher, and he can only have two shots on-screen at the same time. His version of the Fire Storm, while wider than a normal buster-shot, feels rather slow. It also doesn't help that the shots immediately die out if they hit or even kill anything (which becomes a very big issue when it comes to the birds later on).

And here we have the birds. Relating back to what was said before: since Fire Man's shots don't travel through things they kill, it basically means the birds are your worst enemies here. You won't be able to get rid of all of them if the egg hits the ground, so your only option to avoid taking damage is to jump over them.

Almost every Robot Master has a gimmick revolving around their abilities interacting with the stage in some way. Here, it involves slicing up things that can either serve as platforms, or potentially hinder you depending on how you cut them.

As per the 1K subscriber special, it's time to get started on the next series of playthroughs. The overall winner was the initial entry in the "Day in the Limelight" series, followed by a tie with its sequel and Mega Man Next Remix.

In any case, the premise of this game is pretty simple: You play as each of the Robot Masters from the first Mega Man game as you take on the ones from MM2. Each character is pretty faithful to their original counter-parts in how they play (although sometimes, I feel it might be a bit too faithful. You'll see what I mean).
